inference:
From the first congruence, $3+x \equiv 4 \pmod{27}$, so $x \equiv 1 \pmod{27}$.
From the second congruence, $5+x \equiv 9 \pmod{125}$, so $x \equiv 4 \pmod{125}$.
From the third congruence, $7+x \equiv 25 \pmod{343}$, so $x \equiv 18 \pmod{343}$.

We have $x \equiv 1 \pmod{27}$, so $x = 27a + 1$ for some integer $a$.
Then $27a+1 \equiv 4 \pmod{125}$.
$27a \equiv 3 \pmod{125}$.
Multiplying by 19, we get $513a \equiv 57 \pmod{125}$.
Since $513 \equiv 513-4(125) = 513-500 = 13 \pmod{125}$, we have $13a \equiv 57 \pmod{125}$.
Multiplying by 13, we get $169a \equiv 741 \pmod{125}$.
Since $169 \equiv 169-125 = 44 \pmod{125}$ and $741 \equiv 741-5(125)=741-625=116 \pmod{125}$, we have $44a \equiv 116 \pmod{125}$.
Multiplying by 6, we get $264a \equiv 696 \pmod{125}$.
$264 \equiv 264 - 2(125) = 264 - 250 = 14 \pmod{125}$.
$696 \equiv 696 - 5(125) = 696-625 = 71 \pmod{125}$.
Thus $14a \equiv 71 \pmod{125}$.
Multiplying by $14^{-1} \equiv 14^{-1} \equiv 38 \pmod{125}$. $14 \cdot 38 = 532 = 4 \cdot 125 + 32$. $14 \times 38 \equiv 532 \equiv 3 \times 125+32$.
$a \equiv 71 \times 38 \equiv 2700+530 \equiv 3238 \equiv 123 \pmod{125}$.
Thus $a = 125b + 123$.
Then $x = 27(125b + 123) + 1 = 3375b + 3321 + 1 = 3375b + 3322$.
$x \equiv 3322 \pmod{3375}$
$x \equiv 18 \pmod{343}$.
$x \equiv 3322 \pmod{3375}$. $3322 \equiv 3322-9(343)= 3322 - 3087 = 235$.
$x=3322$.
$3322 = 31 \times 105 + 77$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{77}$
ground_truth:
Since $105 = 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7$, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, it suffices to find the remainders when $x$ is divided by $3$, $5$, and $7$. As $3+x$ leaves a remainder of $4$ when divided by $27 = 3^3$, it follows that $3+x \equiv 4 \pmod{3}$, and thus that $x\equiv 1 \pmod{3}$. Similarly, \begin{align*}
x &\equiv 9 \equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\
x &\equiv 25 \equiv 4 \pmod{7}.
\end{align*}As $4 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$, it follows from the Chinese Remainder Theorem that $x \equiv \boxed{4} \pmod{105}$.

inference:
From the given congruences:
$x \equiv 1 \pmod{27}$
$x \equiv 4 \pmod{125}$
$x \equiv 18 \pmod{343}$

Using the Chinese Remainder Theorem, we first find a solution modulo $27 \times 125 = 3375$.
$x \equiv 1 \pmod{27}$
$x \equiv 4 \pmod{125}$
$27a \equiv 3 \pmod{125}$
$a \equiv 123 \pmod{125}$
$x = 27(125b+123) + 1 = 3375b + 3321 + 1 = 3375b + 3322$
$x \equiv 3322 \pmod{3375}$
Now we have
$x \equiv 3322 \pmod{3375}$
$x \equiv 18 \pmod{343}$
$3322 = 9 \times 343 + 235$
$3322 \equiv 235 \pmod{343}$
So $x \equiv 235 \pmod{343}$
We want to solve $x \equiv 235 \pmod{343}$.
$235 = x$.

ground_truth:
Since $105 = 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7$, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, it suffices to find the remainders when $x$ is divided by $3$, $5$, and $7$. As $3+x$ leaves a remainder of $4$ when divided by $27 = 3^3$, it follows that $3+x \equiv 4 \pmod{3}$, and thus that $x\equiv 1 \pmod{3}$. Similarly, \begin{align*}
x &\equiv 9 \equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\
x &\equiv 25 \equiv 4 \pmod{7}.
\end{align*}As $4 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$, it follows from the Chinese Remainder Theorem that $x \equiv \boxed{4} \pmod{105}$.
